( Coca-Cola’s 20 Billion Dollar Brands & Future Growth!!!!! Coca-Cola (KO) has long been a favorite of income investors, due to its impressive history of dividend growth. Coca-Cola has increased its dividend for 58 consecutive years. It has one of the longest active streaks of annual dividend increases in the entire S&P 500 Index. ) What the boycotters are missing is that Coca Cola is more then a soda pop company , and sells its drinks in 200 countries . Minute Maid was Coca-Cola’s first non-carbonated beverage. Coca-Cola acquired Minute Maid in 1960. Coca-Cola has been in the juice business for ~60 years , Minute Maid Pulpy was launched in China in 2005. The company reached billion dollar brand status in 2010,after just 5 years. Simply Orange , Coca-Cola acquired Del Valle in 2007 for a total of $470 million in 2010, Coca-Cola grew Del Valle to reach $1 billion a year in annual sales. Powerade was released in 1988 , Powerade has reached market share of approximately 16% of the sports drink market . Glaceau Vitamin Water was acquired by Coca-Cola in 2007 for $4.1 billion. Along with Vitamin Water, Glaceau also sells Vitamin Water Zero Sugar. The deal was Coca-Cola’s largest acquisition at the time. Aquarius is the leading sports drink in Japan. Coca-Cola also sells water under the Aquarius brand in various countries. Coca-Cola released Aquarius in 1983. Gold Peak tea was released in the United States in 2006. It reached billion dollar brand status by 2014. In 2007 Coca-Cola had 10 billion dollar brands. Just 8 years later, the company reached 20 billion dollar brands. The company sells 2 billion beverage servings every day. Just like the 2014 American the Beautiful boycott the right wing missed the point on how huge a company Coca Cola is , and with Coca Cola acquiring Costa Coffee in 2019 , gives Coca-Cola a strong coffee platform across parts of Europe, Asia Pacific, the Middle East, and Africa . Nobody is going to get rid of James Quincey who has beat wall street's expectations in the last 7 earnings report .

Howard lamented that I "never post about the Dividend (sic) payouts".Two days ago I posted some numbers re KO's, PEP's and VTI's dividend history. I hope it read this post, but just in case, I'll "post (more) about the Dividend (sic) payouts":While pretty meaningless, a FUN! metric is Yield on Cost (YOC).For example, had someone bought KO shares in 1985 (or earlier) @1.68 or lower, their KO position would have a 100% (or greater) YOC.I'm only long two stocks that have YOCs >100%, clocking in @129.4% and 104.4%. I have two other positions that have YOCs of 97.6% & 98.2%. Within the next few months, these positions will also have YOCs >100%.In conclusion, although over the past twenty years KO's dividend policy has only slightly kept ahead of the market's, and it pales over PEP's payout history, over time dividends do grow and they can be a significant portion of one's income.

Maybe KO will regain its mojo--I wouldn't count it out nor do I think it has been or will be impacted by any "boycott".Since 2014, it's dividend growth has significantly trailed its closest peer (PEP) and the market.Dividend growth since 2014:KO 37.7%PEP 89.4%Blend of VOO & SPY 70.5%For those interested in not only an INCREASING income stream, but also capital appreciation (even if one is content with exclusively living on dividends and not touching their principal, it might nonetheless want to grow their principal for the benefit of its heirs), going with a broadly based index fund/ETF would have been the way to go and very well may be the way to go going forward.Full disclosure: Total market funds/ETF represent ~66% of my equity exposure. PEP has a 1.27% weight. No KO position.

( For example, had someone bought KO shares in 1985 (or earlier) @1.68 ) Not a bad investment back in 1985 . 2000 shares of Coca Cola for an investment of $3,360 . So how would that investment be worth today? Coca Cola has had 5 stock splits since 1985 , 3 for 1 in 1986 , and 4 2 for 1 splits in 1990 , 1992 , 1996 , and 2012 so today you would have 96,000 shares of Coca Cola worth $5,156,160 , and a dividend payout of 161,280 a year . Not a bad investment over time

( One of Buffett's most famous investments now pays Berkshire a 50% annual dividend yield on Buffett's initial investment. Not only that, but it's in one of the safest stocks around. Over the course of 1988 and 1989, Buffett took an enormous position in Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO). Due to its rapid gains over the course of 1989, the stock quickly became Berkshire's largest holding by the end of that year . Based on today's dividend, Berkshire will receive $672 million in Coca-Cola dividends for its 400 million shares. This is against Berkshire's overall cost basis of $1,299 million, good for a yield of 51.7%.Oh, and the story should get even better this March, when Coca-Cola typically raises its payout -- something it's done for the past 59 straight years, making it not just a Dividend Aristocrat but a Dividend King. ) This time next year, KO will be at 63.00 a share !!!!!! I based that opinion on what Berkshire Hathaway, Inc , Vanguard Group, Inc , Blackrock Inc. , State Street Corporation , Wellington Management Group, LLP , JP Morgan Chase & Company , Morgan Stanley , 3,168 of Institutions Holding Shares , and 27 brokerage firms rating Coca Cola as a buy , are saying . Boy how did I miss this one?????? The Zacks Research Aug 30th Shares of Coca-Cola have outperformed the Zacks Beverages - Soft drinks industry over the past year (+12.4% vs. +11.8%). The Zacks analyst believes that shares of Coca-Cola outpaced the industry in the past year, thanks to its robust earnings surprise trend that continued in second-quarter 2021. This marked the seventh straight quarter of earnings beats and its second consecutive sales beat.The company’s top line bounced back from the decline witnessed in the prior-year quarter, mainly owing to the increased consumer mobility and reopening of economies in several regions, which led to increased away-from-home channel sales. Revenues reflected gains from improved price/mix, an increase in concentrate sales and higher unit case volume.The company is poised to gain from accelerating investments to expand its digital presence. However, the company witnessed pressures from higher supply chain costs, including transportation and commodity costs. It witnessed higher marketing spends compared with the prior-year quarter.
